provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Inherited from Blake by his wife Catherine upon his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham, probably upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; sold by Tatham to the British Museum in Oct. 1867.

objnote.p: This is one of seven monochrome wash drawings (Objects 37-43) by Blake of figures painted by Michelangelo in the Sistine Chapel. They were very probably copied from the engravings of Adamo Ghisi, after drawings by Giorgio Ghisi, published in *Pitture dipinte nella Volta della Capella Sistina nel Vaticano* (1773). The wash drawing, *Matthan*, is on the recto of this drawing. The British Museum collection stamp appears lower left on the leaf bearing this wash drawing.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This wash drawing shows two male figures: in front is a muscular, partly nude man seated on a large block; behind is a young boy who appears upright, as if on alert. The man is presumably the Abias of the title, a biblical figure listed in Matthew's genealogy of Jesus. Abias faces right as he sits on the block in a contracted posture. His right knee bends at 90 degrees, and Abias's right foot is drawn up the side of the block toward his body. His left leg also bends, but it extends outward from the block so that his left foot rests on the floor. Both feet are bare. A skirt or other garment covers Abias from the waist down; it features some small, jagged pieces near the waist. Abias's body folds in half at the waist, his bare torso leaning over his legs as his muscular right arm dangles toward the ground. A bracelet or cord encircles his wrist. His left hand crosses over to rest on top of his right knee with the fingers curving toward the viewer. Abias's head lowers, turns away from the viewer, and may rest on his right knee. He has short hair, and a cord or other object may wrap around the back of his head and over his right knee. Behind Abias, rising over his hunched back, is a young male figure who does not now appear in Michelangelo's fresco. The boy's torso faces forward and to the right, but his head turns to the left as he looks backward over his right shoulder. The boy appears to wear a shirt or other garment, and there may be a cape or draped cloth over his shoulder. The boy's hair is short and curly. It hovers leftward, over his forehead, as if blown by the wind. The boy and Abias's legs are fainter than Abias's body; shadows appear beneath Abias's torso, along the back of his dangling right arm, and at the boy's back. The block on which the figures sit rests on a bare floor. The background is plain, perhaps representing a bare wall behind the figures.
